text: And the flood was forty days upon the earth; and the waters increased, and bare up the ark, and it was lift up above the earth.
text_kjv: And the flood was forty days upon the earth; and the waters increased, and bare up the ark, and it was lift up above the earth.
text_niv: For forty days the flood kept coming on the earth, and as the waters increased they lifted the ark high above the earth.
text_esv: The flood continued forty days on the earth. The waters increased and bore up the ark, and it rose high above the earth.
text_nlt: For forty days the floodwaters grew deeper, covering the ground and lifting the boat high above the earth.
text_msg: The flood continued forty days and the waters rose and lifted the ship high over the Earth.
text_nasb: Then the flood came upon the earth for forty days, and the water increased and lifted up the ark, so that it rose above the earth.
context: Genesis 7:17 depicts a crucial stage in the unfolding of the Great Flood. In ancient Near Eastern cultures, flooding was a common, devastating occurrence, particularly in the Tigris-Euphrates river valley, the likely setting of the Genesis narrative. Mesopotamian flood myths, like the Epic of Gilgamesh, feature similar catastrophic deluges, suggesting a shared cultural memory of such events. These myths, however, typically portray the gods as capricious and the floods as arising from divine whims or squabbles. The Genesis account, in contrast, presents the flood as a direct consequence of human wickedness and a righteous judgment by a just God. The number forty often symbolizes a period of testing, trial, or preparation in the Bible, as seen in Moses' forty days on Mount Sinai and Jesus' forty days in the wilderness. The description of the ark being 'lift up above the earth' highlights the ark's unique purpose as a vessel of salvation amidst universal destruction. The ancient world held a different understanding of geography and cosmology. The 'earth' as understood then was likely the localized inhabited world. The scale of the flood was likely intended to be understood as a catastrophic event affecting the known world of Noah and his contemporaries, not necessarily a planet-wide, scientifically literal inundation as might be interpreted today. The ark itself would have been an incredible feat of engineering for the time, a massive wooden structure designed for buoyancy and stability. Its construction required significant resources, labor, and, most importantly, faith and obedience from Noah.
meaning: Theologically, Genesis 7:17 underscores the power and sovereignty of God. The flood is not merely a natural disaster; it is a deliberate act of divine judgment against widespread sin and rebellion. The increasing waters represent the overwhelming nature of God's justice, leaving no room for escape or evasion. The ark, in contrast to the destructive forces, symbolizes God's mercy and grace. It is a vessel of salvation, providing refuge for Noah and his family, along with representatives of all living creatures. The ark's being lifted up above the earth signifies God's ability to transcend the consequences of sin and to provide a way of deliverance for those who are faithful. This verse foreshadows the ultimate deliverance found in Jesus Christ, who offers salvation from the judgment of sin and eternal life to all who believe. Just as the ark provided physical salvation during the flood, Jesus provides spiritual salvation from eternal death. The flood serves as a stark reminder of the consequences of sin and the importance of heeding God's warnings. It also highlights the steadfastness of God's love and His provision for those who are righteous in His sight. The ark isn't just a boat; it's a symbol of God's covenant with Noah, a promise of protection and preservation amid chaos. It speaks to God's character as both just and merciful, willing to punish sin but also offering a pathway to redemption. The ark being lifted 'above the earth' also points to the transcendent nature of salvation – it originates from above, from God's grace, and lifts us above the corruption and condemnation of the world.
application: In modern application, Genesis 7:17 challenges us to consider our own response to God's warnings and offers of salvation. The flood serves as a cautionary tale about the consequences of persistent sin and the importance of repentance. Are we living lives that are pleasing to God, or are we contributing to the moral decay of our society? Just as Noah obeyed God's instructions and built the ark, we are called to heed God's Word and to live in accordance with His will. The ark also serves as a reminder of the importance of faith and obedience. Noah faced ridicule and skepticism as he built the ark, but he persevered in his commitment to God. We too may face opposition and challenges as we seek to live out our faith, but we must remain steadfast in our trust in God. Furthermore, the ark highlights the need for community and fellowship. Noah and his family were saved together, emphasizing the importance of supporting and encouraging one another in our spiritual journeys. We are not meant to walk this path alone. We should actively seek out opportunities to connect with other believers and to build strong, supportive relationships. The 'rising waters' can be seen as the challenges, trials, and temptations that we face in life. The ark, in this context, symbolizes the resources and support systems that God provides – His Word, prayer, fellowship, and the Holy Spirit. Just as the ark lifted Noah above the floodwaters, these resources can lift us above the difficulties of life and help us to remain grounded in our faith. Finally, the verse challenges us to examine what we are building our lives upon. Are we building on the shifting sands of worldly values and temporary pleasures, or on the solid foundation of God's Word and eternal truth? Just as the ark was built according to God's specifications, we must build our lives according to His design.
prayer: Sovereign God, Your power is unmatched, and Your justice is undeniable. We are humbled by the story of Noah and the flood, a reminder of the consequences of sin and the depth of Your mercy. Thank you for providing a way of salvation through the ark, and even more so, through Your Son, Jesus Christ. Help us to heed Your warnings and to live lives that are pleasing in Your sight. Grant us the faith and courage to build our lives on the firm foundation of Your Word, and to trust in Your provision during times of trial. Protect us from the rising waters of temptation and despair, and lift us up above the storms of life. Guide us into a life of faithful service to you. Amen.
